body: Thanks! Merged the pull request.
Example services have been already updated as part of I3S  1.5 Spec update.

Hello, 

Does this help?  https://github.com/Esri/i3s-spec/blob/master/format/Indexed%203d%20Scene%20Layer%20Format%20Specification.md#_6_7

Also, I would recommend downloading and inspecting a SLPK such as this one: https://www.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=ecb909417e1e4b36b2db9c7de14f3575

Let us know if you need more information.

hello,
       I want to know the struct of the  geometry.bin file in the slpk file .  e.g.: 1-8 byte is count  is a int32.

      header and body.

     thanksã€‚

> More of a question than an issue.

yes, but a good one! (and apparently something you've considered [before](https://github.com/Esri/raster-functions/pull/39#discussion_r103814331)). i'll see what i can find out.

i got some information from the team and it appears their intention is definitely to allow for different ellipsoids. we'll be thinking about how to clarify this during our next round of updates to the spec.
@w12594822 thanks for the pull request. Merged the url typo for SharedResources example!

Assume we have several images, we put them into one binary file. How we put them? 
Compress images separately then combine them into a single binary file, or 
combine them into a single binary file first, then compress the whole binary file?

How we put the binary file decide us how to decode the texture file. 

Thank you!
The original intent was to compress images individually. I don't think there is much to be gained to compress them again. Maybe one of the current maintainers can comment?

Hey Pengfei,
Combining multiple images into a single binary file is not supported by all clients, so we recommend against using this feature of the i3s spec. Also textures are usually large resources so there is not much to gain from combining them. If you have many small textures, you should consider combining them into a texture atlas.

To answer your question, the offset and length fields are before gzip compression. So for uncompressed image data (eg. S3TC textures), you would combine them in a binary file and then compress them. For compressed formats, like JPEG or PNG, as @thorsten-reitz said you would not use gzip compression at all , so you would just combine the images.

For the `maxScreenThreshold` error metric, `maxError` means that you should replace the node with it's children as soon as the nodes bounding sphere has a screen radius larger than `maxError` pixels. In this sense a value of `0` means you should always load it's children, or if it's a leaf node, you should always display it.
Thank you. It would be good if you could update the spec document.

For showing the question clearly, I paste a screenshot of one data.
![l r1j6 ffgmt3rtfxanc3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25144819/39283864-ee673018-4942-11e8-91c1-2027d9822f58.png)

Strangely, the length is same as the binary file length. When I uncompressed the binary file, the uncompressed data length doesn't equal file length.

The data can be consumed by ArcGIS PRO. So I want to know how to deal with it?
If the length is compressed length, I am afraid that if we combine S3TC textures into one compressed binary file, then we can't split them correctly.

Do you want to modify it manually? It seems it is hard to change the overall height.

You need to change all the node's center at same time. 

According to the spec, you can modify the mbs property. The third parameter in mbs generally represent the node's height.

You could traverse all the node index document, add a same bias height for the third number in mbs. 

Hope it helps.
Oh. Should thank @thorsten-reitz  too.

this problem usually happens when you mix different vertical coordinate systems. Try to make sure all your different software packages agree on the vertical coordinate system. If that does not help, the viewers usually have the option to apply a vertical offset to an existing scene service.

As a last resort, you can try @pengfei666's suggestion or add the following definition to the layer document in the slpk (same as configuring a vertical offset in the viewer):
```
"elevationInfo": {
  "mode": "absoluteHeight",
  "offset": 123.45
}
```
just a shot in the dark, but it is likely recycled from the Web map/Web scene [specification](https://developers.arcgis.com/web-scene-specification/objects/popupInfo/).
Thanks. It might be nice to link to that in the specification.

Hello,

I have a question regarding this issue.

When do I switch the LoD is the maxError is 523.21?

Hi,  
I'm wondering those values in the binary file are little-endian or big-endian?
@CrashedBboy all binary data is little-endian.

The LoD computation works as follows

1. Project bounding sphere on screen plane and compute its radius in pixels. (see eg. here for an example of how to do this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21648630/radius-of-projected-sphere-in-screen-space)
2. Switch LoD to children if this radius is bigger than maxError.

Great, thanks.
I didn't understand it from the example comments.

1. The service you are referring to does not use subimage regions, so the uv coordinates are coordinates of the whole atlas texture.
2. For services that use vertex regions there is an additional vertex attribute with 4 16 bit values that identifies the sub image.

Did you try to flip the v-coordinate? (v = 1 - v) Depending how you define your texture coordinate system this is sometimes necessary.

Hi @sreinhard , the problem's been solved by flipping the v-coordinates.
Now the textures are mapped onto the building correctly.
![texture](https://i.imgur.com/ifA6suj.png)
Thanks a lot!
